utterances: Yes.
I said think of a five-letter word starting with T, as in Thomas, that is plural.
Add an S at the end, and you'll get a six-letter word that is also plural.
What words are these?
And the answer?
Well, first I'll tell you we had a lot of answers like troop and troops, which I didn't accept because they're basically the same word.
The intended answer, and the only one I accepted, is these to theses.
Ah, very good.
We had over 1,200 entries from people who tried to solve the puzzle, and our randomly selected winner is Brian Schnittker from Plano, Texas.
Hello, Brian.
Hi.
What do you do down there?
Well, I'm actually at home for Christmas break.
I'm usually a student in Austin, Texas.
And how long have you been playing the puzzle?
Well, it's kind of a funny story.
Actually, I saw the movie ""Word Play"" a few weeks ago and kind of got interested.

I found out that Will Shortz does this show on NPR, and so I went on the Web site and started to look up some of the shows and saw the clue or the puzzle for this week and thought, oh, what the heck, I'll just send off an answer.
And lo and behold, they called me up.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know what?
You should play the lottery this week.
I think so.
My goodness, this is crazy.
Are you guys ready to play?

As horrific as it is to watch in real time what's happening in Kobani, it's also important to remember you have to step back and understand the strategic objective and where we have begun over the course of the last weeks.
Turkey has been encouraging the U.S.
to do more to support rebels fighting against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's regime and to create a buffer zone inside Syria - a difficult military task.
Kerry reacted cautiously to that idea, as did British Foreign Secretary Hammond.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We are at the stage of exploring, as the secretary said.
This is very new territory.
I mean, we're only in the first week or two of the coalition's existence and operation.
The idea of a buffer zone is one that has been floated.
We'd have to explore with other allies and partners what is meant by a buffer zone - how such a concept would work.
But I certainly wouldn't want to rule it out.
Kerry said only it's worth examining, though U.S.
military officials say a buffer zone is not on the table, and they're asking for, quote, ""strategic patience."" Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
Joanna Kakissis reports from Athens.
More than 40,000 illegal migrants entered Greece last year through the land border with Turkey, says Public Order Minister Christos Papoutsis.
He told the Greek news agency this weekend that the country must build a fence on part of the border and deport those undocumented migrants who are not refugees.
Greece, he says, can no longer accommodate new migrants.
Unemployment here is more than 12 percent.
(Foreign language spoken)
For NPR News, I'm Joanna Kakissis, in Athens.
We're going next to Rwanda, which is holding a presidential election today.
It is only the second time the country has done that since a genocide in 1994.
Rwanda's slow political development contrasts with an amazing economic turnaround.
It is considered one of the more stable and prosperous countries in Africa.
Andrew Harding with the BBC covers Rwanda.
He's on the line from Johannesburg, South Africa.
Welcome to the program.
Yes.
Hi, Steve.
I suppose when we think about a presidential election in Rwanda, we still go directly back to a connection with Rwanda's genocide and that the incumbent is the man who put a stop to it.
Exactly.
Paul Kagame, the man who - the head of a rebel army came in and basically ended the genocide in '94, and has been in power ever since.
He's a former soldier and still has very much a military bearing and a military perspective on things.
And he is seen as one of Africa's most remarkable and most successful presidents.
Can anybody challenge him?
Well, there are three challengers.
But to be honest, people barely know their names.
They're barely campaigning.
They're all from his ruling alliance.
And it does feel a bit more like a coronation than an election.
None of the main opposition figures who are challenging President Kagame more directly was allowed to register or allowed their parties to get on the ballot.
What exactly has the government done to its political opponents?

Well, a range of things, some of which can be directly linked to the government, for instance, the banning of many opposition newspapers, the failure to register certain opposition parties, the fact that some opposition leaders are under house arrest or in prison.
Some other issues cannot be pinned directly onto the government.
And the government has strenuously denied, for instance, any involvement in recent killings in which a prominent journalist was killed.

A former ally of the president who fled to South Africa and was later shot at, he certainly said that that was an attempted assassination by the presidency - and also, the decapitation of a leading opposition politician last month.
And it would be awkward, to say the least, if this president who made his reputation on ending a horrible round of killing was linked to killings.
I mean, obviously, we can't pin these murders directly on President Kagame, and he has denied any involvement in them.
But there is a pattern of intolerance here, a very low threshold for criticism, at the very least, that we are seeing emerge in Rwanda.
And to some extent, it's understandable.
The president does not want a return of those genocidal forces that are still intact and are still talking about revenge and so on.

At the same time, I think a lot of people in the international community - and some within Rwanda - are feeling perhaps he could ease up a little, that he can't go on forever using the genocide as an excuse to crush all political opposition.
So is this likely to count as a free and fair election by the standards of the world?
It's likely to count as an extremely well-run election.
And, yes, I think broadly, the will of the people, if you like, will be represented.
President Kagame's likely to get probably 95 percent again, like he did in 2003.
There is overwhelming support for him.
People do, I think, thank him not only for ending the genocide, but for the extraordinary stability and for the extraordinary economic growth that the country has seen.
It's a tiny country.
It doesn't have much to offer.
But it has grown by six or seven or more percent over the past decade every year.
It's one of the most uncorrupt countries in Africa, one of the most efficient, effective governments.
And as long as that continues, I think people will continue to think that President Kagame is the man for the job.
Andrew Harding of the BBC.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
This is NPR News.

I agree that we're responsible for the content.
But we don't produce the content.

I think that when people ask us if we're a media company or a publisher, my understanding of what the heart of what they're really getting at is, do we feel responsibility for the content on our platform?
The answer to that I think is clearly yes.
This was a very rehearsed, very prepared answer to this long-running question.
For years Facebook has bristled at a comparison to a media company.
And this is sort of the slow acceptance of some responsibility for the content that lives on its platform.
What about Russia...
Right.

...And the attempts by Russia to try to influence American voters in the run-up to the 2016 election, try to influence American politics, you know, past the election and right up to this moment right now?
What did Zuckerberg say about that?
